result.title: SSN Coding Contest — 1 (Editorial)
result.content:
A — Sereja and Mugs (http://codeforces.com/problemset/problem/426/A)

Each player takes a non — empty mug. Therefore all cups will be choosen in the end. If the sum of all the volumes other than largest element are less than or equal to the volume of cup, print yes, else no.

B — Petya and Strings (http://codeforces.com/problemset/problem/112/A)

Convert both strings to lower case and use comparison functions in stl. (strcmp, strcmpi for a direct answer)

C — Flipping Game (http://codeforces.com/problemset/problem/327/A)

The goal is to obtain maximum ones. A "Brute force" solution where you consider every segment to flip will get it accepted. However, there is a smarter way of doing it using a technique called "dynamic programming", which i will not talk about now. Let us go one step at a time ;)

D — Increase and Decrease (http://codeforces.com/problemset/problem/246/B)

If the sum of all values of the given array is divisble by n, answer is n, otherwise it's (n — 1). I encourage you guys to think about the proof :)

E — Dima and Continuous Line (http://codeforces.com/problemset/problem/358/A)

Editorial Courtesy: Sereja (The problem-writer)

If our line has self-intersections, that some pair of semi-circles exists, which intersect each other. Let points x1 < x2 are connected with a semi-circle and points x3 < x4 are connected with another semi-circle. Then this semis-circles intersect if one of the conditions is true:

1). x1 < x3 < x2 < x4 2). x3 < x1 < x4 < x2

Let’s iterate trough all pairs of semi-circles, and check if the semi-circles intersect each other
